Framework Purpose & Context ### **Why This Framework Exists** Mosul's green housing sector faces a **skills-to-employment gap**: - **Trainers confirm**: *"CVs aren't trusted. We need to see people work with their hands."* (Zeina Tareq, Solar Expert) - **Fresh graduates struggle**: Limited professional networks, no portfolio of real projects, unclear entry points - **Employers hesitate**: Hiring is risky without evidence of competence; trial periods are standard This framework provides **low-risk pathways** for trainees to gain practical experience, build portfolios, connect with suppliers and customers, and transition into employment or entrepreneurship. ### **The Critical Foundation: Building Customer Demand** **MOST IMPORTANT INSIGHT**: The success of job placement and new businesses depends on **creating customer appetite for green housing solutions**. You cannot hire solar installers if no one is buying solar systems. You cannot launch an insulation consultancy if homeowners don't see the value. Therefore, this framework integrates **three parallel tracks**: 1. **Supply Side**: Training skilled practitioners (solar installers, energy consultants, green architects) 2. **Demand Side**: Building awareness and appetite among homeowners, developers, and institutions 3. **Market Connections**: Linking supply to suppliers, customers, and each other **Advocacy and awareness-raising are not "nice-to-haves" — they are foundational** to creating jobs. ### **Three Different Career Outcomes** The BEIT training modules prepare participants for **three distinct outcomes**, each requiring a different apprenticeship approach: | Module | Career Goal | Focus | |--------|-------------|-------| | **Insulation** | **Entrepreneurship** | Energy consulting is a new field and requires opening new consulting / retrofitting services | | **Solar** | **Employment** | Join existing solar company as technician / installer to start, then potentially starting their own | | **Architecture** | **Leadership in Field - Awareness & Design** | Influence clients toward heritage-informed green design | **Implication**: Each industry has different challenges and requirements so we customized each training to have a tailored pathway for each track. --- ## 2. Placement Process ### **3.1 Pre-Training: Preparing the Ground** **IP Coordinator Actions (2-3 weeks before training starts)**: 1. **Identify 15-20 potential mentors** across all three tracks: - Insulation: 3-5 experienced energy consultants / retrofit experts - Solar: 5-8 solar company owners / lead installers - Architecture: 5-7 senior architects with green/heritage experience 2. **Conduct mentor orientation** (1-hour session): - Explain apprenticeship model, salary subsidy, portfolio requirements - Share Module Learning Outcomes to align expectations - Gather mentor preferences (how many apprentices can they take? when?) - Sign Mentor Agreement (Template B) 3. **Brief trainees during training** (Day 1 or 2): - Explain pathways (shadowing → apprenticeship → first project → Festival) - Set expectation: *"Your first project starts the week after training ends"* - Introduce portfolio requirements and content creation expectations - Explain credentialing and how certificates support professional identity --- ### **3.2 During Training: Activating Connections** **Supplier Introductions (All Tracks)**: - **Insulation**: SIKA representative presents products, pricing, bulk order discounts (Day 2) - **Solar**: Equipment vendor demonstrates panels, inverters, provides contact info (Day 3) - **Architecture**: Heritage materials supplier showcases options, green material vendors present (Day 2-3) **Trainer as Talent Scout**: - Trainers observe trainees during hands-on exercises - Identify high-potential candidates for their companies or networks - Make informal recommendations to IP coordinator - Commit to site visit support for trainees' first 1-2 projects **Real Client Connections (Architecture Track)**: - Mosul Space sources real homeowners/developers willing to receive free design consultations - Each trainee paired with client during training - Trainees practice client interviews, site assessments, pitching green/heritage design **Content Creation Embedded**: - **Daily documentation**: Trainees photograph demos, materials, their own work - **Social media practice**: Trainees post 1-2 updates during training week to start building online presence - **Peer feedback**: Cohort reviews each other's content, suggests improvements --- ### **3.3 Post-Training Week 1: Immediate Activation** **Within 48 hours of training completion**: 1. **IP Coordinator sends personalized message** to each trainee: - *"Congratulations! Your first project starts NOW. This week, [specific action based on track]."* - Insulation: *"Conduct energy audit on your own home. Document with photos. Share in WhatsApp group by Friday."* - Solar: *"Contact [Trainer X] to schedule your first installation assist. Confirm by Wednesday."* - Architecture: *"Finalize your custom client design. Begin Model Home Design Award submission."* 2. **Trainers confirm site visit schedule**: - Trainer and trainee agree on 1-2 dates for QA visits during Week 2-4 projects - IP coordinator tracks confirmations, follows up on delays 3. **WhatsApp community activation**: - Trainees share progress daily (photos, challenges, wins) - Trainers provide remote troubleshooting - Peer support and encouragement --- ### **3.4 Week 2-4: Matching & Placement** **Matching Process**: 1. **Trainee submits "apprenticeship interest form"** (Template A) indicating: - Preferred companies/mentors (if employment track) - Availability (days/week, hours/day) - Portfolio pieces from Week 1 project 2. **IP Coordinator reviews applications** with trainer input: - Prioritize trainees who completed Week 1 activation successfully - Match based on mentor capacity, trainee skill level, geographic proximity 3. **Mentors review trainee profiles**: - Portfolio from Week 1 project - Trainer recommendation - Hands-on test results (if applicable) 4. **Matching meeting** (in-person or WhatsApp call): - Trainee + mentor discuss expectations, schedule, learning goals - If both agree, sign Apprenticeship Agreement (Template B) - Set start date (ideally within 1 week) 5. **Onboarding** (Template C: Learning Plan + Template E: Safety): - Mentor creates customized learning plan (Week 1 tasks, Week 2 tasks, etc.) - Trainee receives safety orientation, insurance info - IP coordinator schedules Week 1 check-in --- ### **3.5 Ongoing Support (Month 1-3)** **Weekly Check-ins**: - **Week 1**: IP coordinator calls trainee + mentor separately (15 min each) to troubleshoot - **Week 2-4**: WhatsApp updates (trainee sends photo + 1-sentence summary daily) - **Monthly**: In-person cohort gathering (all 15 trainees + IP coordinator) to share experiences **Trainer Site Visits** (First 2 Projects Only): - Trainer visits site during project execution (1-2 hours) - Provides QA, builds customer confidence (*"My ustādh approves this work"*) - Troubleshoots technical issues in real-time - Trainee takes photo with trainer + customer for portfolio **Problem-Solving Protocol**: - If trainee struggles: Mentor adjusts learning plan, IP coordinator provides extra support - If mentor-trainee mismatch: IP coordinator facilitates respectful exit, matches trainee with new mentor - If safety concern: Immediate halt, investigation, corrective action (see Section 6) --- ### **3.6 Evaluation & Transition (Month 2-3)** **Apprenticeship Evaluation** (Template D: Evaluation Rubric): - Mentor assesses trainee on technical skills, soft skills, work ethic (1-5 scale) - Trainee reflects on learning, challenges, goals (written self-assessment) - IP coordinator reviews both, provides feedback **Outcomes**: - **Employment track (Solar)**: If evaluation ≥ 4/5 average, employer offers full hire at market rate - **Entrepreneurship track (Insulation, Architecture)**: Trainee completes 1-2 paid projects, builds client pipeline - **Portfolio complete**: Trainee has 3-5 documented projects, ready to showcase at Green Housing Festival **Green Housing Festival Preparation** (See Section 8): - Trainees prepare booth displays, presentation slides, Model Home Design Award submissions - IP coordinator coordinates logistics, marketing, media outreach --- ## 4.
